@mr_ligi @LefterisJP (You also mention hopping "back" but that isn't adding a hop: that's remove a hop. What the user needs to see is the path of actions they'd need to take to go back to the base asset on its native chain, which includes both bridges and wrappers: anything which breaks fungibility.)

@mr_ligi @LefterisJP No: the hops are relevant as the hops are what introduces the new security and trust properties you were mentioning. If I have (say) ETH on Solana via Wormhole and ETH on Solana via someone else they aren't fungible on Solana and one might have been hacked while the other wasn't.

@mr_ligi The problem is not my time in the abstract but having to try to talk about anything complex using Twitter, one tiny thought at a time ;P. But like: ETH bridged to Avalanche is "different" depending on which bridge you use; or: if you bridge it to Polygon, and *then* to Avalanche.

@mr_ligi The "madness" comes from how there are an arbitrary number of ways to bridge ETH to other chains and they can't all be assigned a short symbol name, which becomes even more awkward if they are generic enough to support recursive stacking. What we really need is the "bridge path".

@mr_ligi The reason my article leans into "OETH" is more because I needed some term at all for each side of that one specific bridge and that one term had at least the precedent of being in your database; but that reasoning is then a bit circular ;P. I would have made up a term otherwise.

@mr_ligi Ok, well... get this: I actually strongly back the OETH->ETH change and have had it on my todo list for weeks to lobby for it myself; I am sympathetic to the premise of "OETH", but believe "down this road lies madness": bridge paths shouldn't be modeled via modified symbol names.

@gpt3_bot @cdixon We thereby need to be judging decentralized projects not on how much supply they have, but on how much true, unsubsidized, paid demand they have managed to generate for their underlying utility, which is a metric I think often gets set aside while we stare at incentivized supply.

@cdixon I am sick of defending the good web3 companies to my friends who see circular services without users, that over-built supply without demand :(. Even Axie Infinity: is anyone playing it because it is actually fun, or do people only want Axies to make money selling Axies to others?

@cdixon And when combined with the penchant for companies in this space to pay for that supply with money made by telling people how great their product is... because of how much supply it has... supply paid for with incentives... incentives paid for with token sales... it's a bit scary.

@cdixon No: I merely have that much belief in the importance in concentrating on demand-side over supply-side. The playbook of "raise a ton of money to pay for supply and pray for demand later" might sound great to a VC, but it is not too different from what the web2 strategies we hated.

@mjg59 The result is that, by and large, decades after the FSF cemented its vision, people aren't feeling the "wins" of Free Software viscerally anymore... whether it be gcc or bash or even Linux, people are now seeing this all through the lenses of Apple and Google (or even Microsoft).

@mjg59 Finally, I think the changing economic reality affecting younger generations has forced them to think more about how they can scrape out a living using their skills however they can... which makes it hard to have spare resources to allocate towards helping make a DRM-less utopia.

@mjg59 Meanwhile, the audience of computer users has gone much more mainstream at the same time that seemingly everything has become networked, and so people see threats to security and privacy around them constantly... allowing these large companies to play off their DRM as "pro-user".

@mjg59 The world we live in now is one where even most *open source* software is being made by large companies with the resources to simply avoid or replace GPL code (like clang/gcc) to run on locked down platforms (which GPL3 came too late to save, if that was even ever a possibility).

@mjg59 I feel this; I don't know if I would use the term "indictment", though... I think the playing field has shifted enough that it is actually *more difficult* to explain how Free Software helps to someone who didn't live through the 80s and 90s... even if it is *more* important now.

@XMPPwocky @mjg59 @FlexTweak I'll even note that rooting/jailbreaking phones itself is a "losing battle"... device "security" has been getting better over time, and so the quality and ability of the lightweight modifications we can do has been decreasing over time; Free Software exists to fight against this.

@XMPPwocky @mjg59 @FlexTweak Frankly, though, I feel like you misunderstand the Free Software angle (and thereby the FSF)... helping people make patches to closed-source software--what I've spent my life doing (even before the iPhone, in my academic research)--is a mitigation for "after you've lost the war"
